qa_pairs.question: What is Angelo Wilson's view on the current public transportation planning in the city?
qa_pairs.answer: He believes that the city should provide buses all over for people to travel around, rather than cutting bus lines due to low usage. He criticizes the focus on designing streets for autonomous vehicles, which he sees as a profit-making proposition, rather than for bus routes.
qa_pairs.source_text: you maybe put 30 bus lines to City College from every place in the city you dont cut the bus lines because it doesnt have the people or whatever you know um you just provide buses all over the city for people to go around back and forth then then theres no need for them to have the cars you know you can stop the planning for bus routes I mean for for city streets you dont you dont design the streets for what they call it whats this new driving self-driving yeah you dont design streets for autonomous vehicles you design them for bus routes

qa_pairs.question: How does Angelo Wilson perceive the city's development and its impact on people?
qa_pairs.answer: He feels that the city's development is driven by profit, not by concern for people. He mentions that everything the city does is to make money, and people are paying taxes for nothing.
qa_pairs.source_text: everything the city does is to make somebody some money its not they dont give a damn about people its obvious anybodys almost receiving and knows theyre getting screwed theyre paying taxes for nothing

qa_pairs.question: What does Angelo Wilson say about the historical integration efforts in San Francisco schools?
qa_pairs.answer: He describes how integration was superficial, with black and white students being separated in practice despite being in the same school. He recalls being on the white side of the playground as an Army brat, while black students were on the other side.
qa_pairs.source_text: when I went to Winfield Scott as a army brat they were integrating San Francisco back in early 60s and they would ship in kids from the Fillmore to Winfield Scott Winfield Scott is now clearly lillianthal in the Marina District when they shipped when they talked about um what do you call integration they would ship to people from The Fillmore in to Winfield Scott but they would they would go to separate classes youd have one side of the playground all black the other side because I was an Army rat I was in the white side of the playground so they had integration but they didnt integrate on on the books it was supposedly happening but they separated the kids

qa_pairs.question: What does Angelo Wilson say about the disparity in educational resources?
qa_pairs.answer: He highlights the discrepancy in resources between schools, noting that at Andrew Jackson, students used ragged books, while at Argonne, they were throwing away brand new books.
qa_pairs.source_text: when I went to Andrew Jackson all the school supplies were all up um death squirrel and disarray teachers were having breakdowns kids were bad but they had lousy teachers and then I got into a fight with somebody and the guy put a couple of stitches in my eye my mother said youre not going to school anymore I went down down the road a mile and a half to Argonne and they were throwing away brand new books week at Andrew Jackson they were studying out of ragged books and in Oregon theres throwing away brand new books I mean old book in Andrew Jackson they were studying out of raggedy books and when I went to Oregon they were throwing away the same books that were brand new never passed out because they were changing over to new books so resources theres a discrepancy in resources

qa_pairs.question: What is Angelo Wilson's perspective on the development of mixed neighborhoods?
qa_pairs.answer: He believes in the importance of developing mixed neighborhoods with people of different financial backgrounds living side by side, similar to his experience in the Presidio, which was subsidized by the government.
qa_pairs.source_text: oh yeah mixed neighborhoods people of different finances living side by side um you know people of different values living side by side this Presidio for me it was subsidized housing the government paid for by housing a government made sure that I got a good school right in summertime I got out in the middle of the you know early in the morning and I played until the sun went down that was my existence for thresidia I think that could be in San Francisco the same thing in San Francisco in general but I think because it was subsidized by the government profit was not the motive

qa_pairs.question: What does Angelo Wilson suggest about the role of wealthy individuals in the city?
qa_pairs.answer: He suggests that wealthy individuals should give back to the city, not for tax benefits, but because the city has granted them a wonderful life. He mentions historical examples of rich people giving back to the city.
qa_pairs.source_text: fly shacker gave back he made a pool you know De Young Museum there was who was that um flood I dont know if flood was a but rich people used to give back to the city because they got from the city and you need a a new um class of rich people that thinks thats what they need to do not because its beneficial for taxes or whatever but they understand I and this is what was explained to me that when they go to the nice little parties that if you have a bunch of poor people living around you you dont come back too much in your house and in order to you pay insurance everybody pays insurance pay insurance you get back to the city because the city has granted you a Wonderful Life and part of the insurance is that the people less than you want a wonderful life too
